thread.title: Brexit could help narrow the North-South divide says survey

author: Mike Kelly
title: Brexit could help narrow the North-South divide says survey
text:

The North-South divide has widened in the last five years and Brexit could help narrow it, according to a new survey. 
It was carried out on behalf of the Policy North think tank and of those asked, 31% said leaving the EU could help rebalance the economy to be more fair. 
Only more spending on infrastructure had a bigger result nationally with 40% of respondents saying it would have a positive impact on the economic divide. 
In all 2,003 people across the UK were quizzed online by independent polling agency Censuswide for Policy North. EU and Union flags (Image: PA) 
The North East breakdown of figures differed from the national result. While 41% thought spending on transport and infrastructure was the best way to narrow the gap and was consistent with the national figure, the Northern Powerhouse project (12%) came next followed by Brexit at 11%. 
In the North East, 49% of those asked thought the divide had widened since 2013, 30% thought it had stayed the same and 5% believed it had narrowed. 
A lack of opportunities to progress careers and earn more in the North emerged from the study as a key marker of the divide. European Parliament Brexit co-ordinator Guy Verhofstadt (left) arrives in Downing Street, London, for talks with Brexit Secretary David Davis (Image: PA) 
UK workers were asked about the number of such opportunities within a 25-mile radius of where they live. 
Of respondents in London, 31% said there were ‘lots of opportunities’ near them, compared to just 8% in the North East. Read More The new North South divide that is getting bigger - this time it's adult skills 
In each Northern region, over a third said there were ‘few opportunities’ to earn more. 
Respondents also listed soaring house prices in the South, and a feeling that the simmering push for Scottish independence has marginalised parts of the North, among other signs of a divide. Stephen Purvis, founder and Group CEO of SGP Technology 
Policy North chairman, Stephen Purvis, said: “The North-South divide is very real and remains a big challenge to crack. Businesses we talk to are clear that they don’t want a bigger begging bowl and exporting jobs from the south is not a sustainable solution. 
“Manchester has shown that with devolved powers comes real cash and the ability for local leaders to set their own priorities, but there is also an east-west divide. We need an equally strong, outward looking, global vision for the North East and Yorkshire, that is not simply built around slightly quicker journey times between regions. Read More The nine projects that show the North-South investment gap DOES exist 
“Leaving the EU will enable us to create free trade zones around existing port infrastructure. If the major ports in the north were given free port status, they could generate hundreds of thousands of jobs and inject billions of pounds into local economies. It would be the most effective northern economic development programme by any government. 
“Ownership of our own state support rules would, for example, allow the soft-launch of a direct Newcastle to London City flight route; much needed by the growing financial and digital sectors. A dedicated report on this is already underway within Policy North.” Like us on Facebook
